Comment: Here is a refreshing reminder never to give up.  Or if you prefer, the stupid loss of a pawn is never the end of the game.

I have bee experimenting with the Center Counter (Scandinavian) Defense as an alternative to the French Defense and other fairly rock-ribbed defenses.  Especially when its reputation seems to be a bit suspect, both for the early forced arrival of the black queen to the center, and also for the easy development for white that buys time to build a strong position.  And yet, it does not die, making me think that if grandmasters play it, then I can certainly try it.
The first surprise.  I was expecting the conventional 3. Nc3 Qd6 or Qa5, etc.
The first surprise.  I was expecting the conventional 3. Nc3 Qd6 or Qa5, etc.
The first surprise.  I was expecting the conventional 3. Nc3 Qd6 or Qa5, etc.
There seems little reason not to apply some pressure early.

A queen trade before the sixth move?  From my research, it appeared there were many instances of this very sequence in grandmaster practice.  Does an early queen trade presage an early draw?  In those games and in this, there is little opportunity for a draw.  I also considered 4...Qh5 5. Be2 Nc6 6. O-O  0-0-0  7. d3  Nf6 8. h3 Bd7 9. Bf4 Qf5 10. Bg3 g5 11. a4 h5 12. h4 gxh4 13. Nxh4 Qh7 from Westphal-Kiel, Landesliga Ost in 2002.  Kiel won this game, but only after some serious torture in the middle-game.  Still other options at black's fourth move include 4....Qa5, 4...Qd6, and 4...Qd8.

A queen trade before the sixth move?  From my research, it appeared there were many instances of this very sequence in grandmaster practice.  Does an early queen trade presage an early draw?  In those games and in this, there is little opportunity for a draw.  I also considered 4...Qh5 5. Be2 Nc6 6. O-O  0-0-0  7. d3  Nf6 8. h3 Bd7 9. Bf4 Qf5 10. Bg3 g5 11. a4 h5 12. h4 gxh4 13. Nxh4 Qh7 from Westphal-Kiel, Landesliga Ost in 2002.  Kiel won this game, but only after some serious torture in the middle-game.  Still other options at black's fourth move include 4....Qa5, 4...Qd6, and 4...Qd8.
5...Nf6 6. Qxe6 Bxe6 is certainly possible.  Alternatives include 5...c6 and 5...Nc6.
5...Nf6 6. Qxe6 Bxe6 is certainly possible.  Alternatives include 5...c6 and 5...Nc6.

6...c6 and 7...Nd7 is another option, in order to keep the queen-side available for long castling.  Or not to castle at all, which occurred in Slingerland-Caspi, Unive open in 2010.  Caspi won that game.

6...c6 and 7...Nd7 is another option, in order to keep the queen-side available for long castling.  Or not to castle at all, which occurred in Slingerland-Caspi, Unive open in 2010.  Caspi won that game.

White can apply some pressure starting with 7. h3 Bh5 8. g4 Bg6 9. Bb5 e6 10. Ne5 Ne7 11. d3 0-0-0 12. Bxc6 Nxc6 13. Nxg6 hxg6 14. Be3 Be7 15. f4 Nb4, but black seems to hold well and eventually wins this game (Laubert-Kasparov, S., 23rd Czech Open A in Pardubice, CZE, 2012).

Once white has played 7. d3, which locks in his king's bishop, I saw no reason to hold back 7...e5.  7...e5 restrains his 8. Bf4 and the problems on c7 that occur after 9. Nb5.  Of course, 8. Nb5 is still possible, and it seems to force 8...Rc8.  So it may be that 7...a6 before 8....e5 is best.
I debated about playing 9...a6 first, simply to avoid some complications starting with 10. Nb5.  But I decided that it was best to protect my bishop at g4 first.

I could only hope to keep up the pressure on the second rank and maybe force some concession later.  But I was down pawn with no serious compensation.  The loss seemed slow but certain.
